I remember as a kid, I was kinda sad of not being able to see rocket lauches live in tv.
But now with SpaceX, and their live reports on Youtube, ON FRIEKIN YOUTUBE, I'm not gonna miss a launch, if I wanted to!

DUDE! I've asked this before - Please DO NOT put spoilers in your titles. For those of us who catch up on your live streams at a later date (i.e. this morning), its incredibly annoying that you put spoilers in there. Fine, do what you want with the cut version, but if we have the YouTube notifications for the live stream, its still accessible to us. Please!

Great video as always, but please don't put spoilers in your video titles. (At least not immediately)
There is an upside if nothing else we now know the block 5 can land with rcs and engines
Watching from Jacksonville https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_Um9eRjAces&lc=z221w1bbosyjztldpacdp435w1opd1tedyoa0wwu2ztw03c010c

The fins opened very slowly. Usually they open quickly. Was that an early sign of hydraulic pump trouble? If that's the case, maybe better to leave fins in neutral position? Spin seems especially hard to control for engines as gimbaling the center engine doesn't counter z axis rotation. Why didn't I see the cold gas thrusters trying to mitigate?
"This is landing back on land" TD2018
It was not a grid fin getting stuck. None of the grid fins were moving. You'd expect three working fins to be able to cancel out any spin of a stuck fin.

You say the booster landings don’t matter to anybody but SpaceX, but I disagree. It does demonstrate that there was some kind of hiccup in their quality control processes that could propagate to the second stage.

Great job with a real-time "space disaster." It was like watching Walter Cronkite trying to put together a Gemini or Apollo landing glitch story in real time. No, seriously.
The vectoring nozzles managed to cancel out the spin. Reached touchdown speed? Looked like it could just maybe have landed intact at LZ 1. Your guesstimate on this? Of course never happen, targeting ocean right thing to do. But... a testament to the robustness of the landing algorithm.
The whole landing system is designed to fail. The tail landing system is an unreliable design in my uneducated opinion.
I just uploaded a new documentary, please watch it and subscribe to my Youtube channel. Thanks
Hi Tim, what headset are you using?

Mad props Tim, just the quickness and speed in which you were able to correctly figure out what went wrong and gather information from other sources to piece together what happened (all while doing a live show) was nothing short of astounding. No one else does live commentary like you do. Keep it up, you inspire me and all of my friends everyday.
I'll be the first one to blame it on those ULA snipers.

I love the applause from the SpaxeX crew in the background upon safely splashing down. Its easy for someone to bash on SpaceX unknowing of how serious of an accomplishment it is that the control systems here were able to safely stabilize and guide this rocket despite a full grid-fin failure.
